<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap:
```c
void metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap(struct metal_bus *bus,
				 struct metal_device *device,
				 uint32_t dir,
				 struct metal_sg *sg,
				 int nents)
{
	int i;
	(void)bus;
	(void)device;
	(void)dir;

	for (i = 0; i < nents; i++) {
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg[i].virt, sg[i].len);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg[i].virt, sg[i].len);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this fragment. The function metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap calls metal_cache_invalidate, not itself. Rule 17.2 would be violated only if there is recursion — for example if metal_cache_invalidate (directly or via a call chain) called metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap, creating an indirect recursive cycle (metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap -> metal_cache_invalidate -> ... -> metal_generic_dev_dma_unmap). There is no evidence of such recursion in the provided fragment.
